properties.name: Lund Cathedral
properties.shortnarra: An astronomical clock at the front, a stone giant holding up the foundations of the cathedral and a carved well in the bowels of a creepy crypt. What more could you want?

properties.name: Finn The Giant - Lund Cathedral Crypt
properties.shortnarra: He's actually quite little. But still looks mean. And, if we're to believe he's holding the cathedral up, strong too.

properties.name: Titchfield Abbey

properties.name: Clutter's Cave
properties.shortnarra: Enigmatic cave no more than four feet in height. Legend has it that a giant lived here - hence its other name 'The Giant's Cave'. If a giant did live here, he must have had an awfully bad back.

properties.name: Swansea Castle
properties.shortnarra: Founded by Henry de Beaumont in 1106. Various rebuilding and demolition have left what remains. This has been consolidated and opened up to view from the street.

properties.name: Rye Castle (Ruin)

properties.shortnarra: The Ypres Tower is one of the oldest buildings in Rye, built as a fortification in 1249. It later became a private dwelling, then a prison, a mortuary, and finally a museum.

properties.narrative:
Water Polo - like normal polo, but without the horses. Or the mallets.

Kalkbrottet is approximately 1300 meters long, 800 meters wide and 65 meters deep. If you walk around the crime has been done a walk of 4 km.
In some limestone layers there are plenty of sharks' teeth.

There are other amusing and interesting sculptures and artworks colouring the city - a high percentage of which are on Kaufman-owned buildings.

We salute you.

properties.name: Hever Castle
properties.narrative: The original moated castle was built in 1270 and consisted of a massive gatehouse and a walled bailey, approached by a wooden drawbridge. In the late 15th century the castle had a comfortable Tudor house built within the walls.
properties.shortnarra: Hever Castle is an attractive fortified manor house surrounded by a moat.

You know the Nobel peace price! This where they hand it out!
The charicaristic two towers. But check out the back where the entrance is... magnificent!

properties.name: Statue of George Washington
properties.shortnarra: The first president of the United States of America.

properties.shortnarra: Along with Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament, the bridge has become one of the icons of London

properties.narrative: The museum's main attraction is a dark, barrel-vaulted room, completely covered with fresco paintings. The 800 sq.m. fresco Vita depicts human life from conception till death, in dramatic and often explicitly erotic scenes.

The original Stave Church from Gol.
Was built in 1216 but some parts are from 1157.

properties.name: Oslo Opera House - The Norwegian National Opera & Ballet
properties.address: Olso central station and walk towards the sea! Kirsten Flagstads pl. 1

properties.narrative: It was listed in 2009 as part of a larger conservation of roads in Norway, with the following statement: "The road is probably the oldest main road to / from Oslo, with at least 800 years.

properties.name: Kit's Coty House
properties.shortnarra: Looks very much like a part of Stonehenge. This is a megalithic open burial chamber of a Neolithic long barrow (grave), about 5,000 years old. The barrow has disappeared but this fine monument survives

properties.narrative: Not much is known about it. Exercise caution - there are VERY deep crevices and cave systems around here!!!

properties.name: Anthony Gormley Statues
properties.narrative: <font color="#000000">An interesting installation of cast iron figures, spaced out along the beach, each staring out westwards. The changing tides and time of day allow you a different view of the statues; some are half swallowed by the tide, others comp

properties.name: 25 Stoke Newington Common
properties.narrative: Marked by a plaque by Hackney Council. So it must be right. Home of the T-Rex frontman for 15 years. If that's not a stamp of approval for Stokey, we don't know what is.
properties.address: 25 Stoke Newington Green, Stoke Newington, London
properties.shortnarra: Marc Bolan's (T-Rex) Old House

properties.name: Lewes Castle
properties.narrative:
It was built by William de Warenne, around 1069-70, and became the main seat for his family. In 1088, William was made Earl of Surrey, and the title continued until 1347, with the death of the last of the line, John de Warenne, the 8th Earl.

Th
properties.address: 169 High Street, Lewes, East Sussex, BN7 1YE
properties.shortnarra: Lewes is a rare example of a castle that has two mottes associated with one bailey (see Lincoln Castle, for the other).

properties.name: Farleigh Hungerford Castle
properties.narrative:
Started in the 14th century this fortified mansion was occupied for 300 years by the Hungerford family and today their gruesome stories are told through a free audio tour. 

There are many hidden treasures to this castle - the chapel wit
properties.shortnarra: In a picturesque valley of the river Frome, on the border between Wiltshire and Somerset, stoops the haughty remains of Farleigh Hungerford Castle.

properties.name: The Watchman's Hut
properties.narrative: <font color="#000000">The New River was intended as a supply of clean drinking water for local residents of this area. This surviving shelter is the only one of several which were dotted along the New River to 'watch' out for anybody who might pollute th

properties.name: Gateposts of Halnaby Hall
properties.narrative:
The house, which was built in 1661 with the wings added in the 18th century, was demolished in 1952.

The Stables, the Victorian walled gardens, the old servants? quarters, the gamekeepers? cottage, various farmsteads and these lodge gatehouses r
properties.shortnarra: One of the only visible remainders of the once grand Halnaby Hall, residence of Anne Isabella Milbanke, who was to become Lady Byron and then Baroness Byron. Yes, she was Lord Byron's other half.

properties.name: "The Old Bailey"
properties.narrative: Part of the present building stands on the site of the medieval Newgate Gaol, on "Old Bailey", a road which follows the line of the City of London's fortified wall (otherwise known as a 'b
properties.address: Central Criminal Court Old Bailey London EC4M 7EH
properties.shortnarra: More properly called "The Central Criminal Court", this place positively REEKS of history.

properties.narrative:
And it was said ?for the good of man kind and to end all wars?.

Read the ;story.

properties.name: Viewpoint
properties.shortnarra: Check out the great view!

properties.name: Pickering Castle
properties.narrative:
Later kings obviously swayed by the excellent heritage of the castle (it's basically like having a famous architect having designed your home), favoured this castle.

Gradually, they each replaced the wooden parts with stone. By the mid 1500s, the
properties.shortnarra: Norman motte and bailey castle, built in wood by William the Conqueror (nonetheless) as a base to crush the rebellion happening in the North of England.

properties.name: Pevensey Castle
properties.narrative: The Roman fort, named Anderida, was built in about AD 290. It is one of the largest surviving examples in Britain, with two thirds of its walls and towers still standing to almost their original height. Unlike most Roman forts that were built to a sta

properties.name: Nymphaeum
properties.narrative: Named after the nymphs ? female nature spirits of classical mythology ? this structure was characteristic of most Graeco-Roman cities; Petra was no exception. As a civic ornament, it functioned both as a repository for water and as a lively meeting place
properties.shortnarra:
Nymphaeum (100 ? 200 A.D.)
A Nymphaeum, or public drinking fountain, once adorned the eastern end of Petra?s Colonnaded Street.

properties.name: Water dam and the water tunnel
The Temple of Dushares (Qasr al Bint)
High Place of Sacrifice
properties.narrative: From the High Place, one can view much of Petra from above. Beautiful scenery. It can get cold and windy up there. The trek down the back side of the mountain reveals many interesting tombs and carvings that might be missed by the average tourist. The ro
properties.shortnarra: The site at the top of the mountain contains elaborate rock altars used for sacrifices.

properties.name: The Oldest Bridge in England
properties.shortnarra: Known as the Tarr Steps, this bridge is made of large 1-2 tonne slabs, laid on top of supports, making steps across the river. The bridge is thought to date from around 1000BC.

properties.name: Tumuli (Bronze Age Burial Mounds)

properties.name: Little Doward Hill Fort
properties.shortnarra: Iron Age Hillfort, slightly difficult to make out, but definitely there!

properties.shortnarra: Communism is dead

properties.name: Former Burial Ground
properties.shortnarra: The piece of land which is now called East Greenwich Pleasaunce was a burial ground for those souls who had lost their fight for life whilst at Greenwich Hospital.

properties.name: Herstmonceux Castle

Today you can explore the whole of the castle, from the storerooms to 
the first-floor captain?s residence. Take a walk around the defences and

properties.shortnarra: Inspiration which caused The Brothers Grimm to write 'Sleeping Beauty'. This is supposedly where she was sleeping all those years

It was the scene of medieval miracle plays performed by the parish clerks of London and it was mentioned by William Fitzstephen in his description of the city as early as 1174.

Until the dissolution of the monasteries, the well was located i

properties.shortnarra: Known locally as 'The Coade Lion', made of a mystery stone (no-one knows how to make it anymore)

The house was built on a low-lying island. Marshland was all around it. There was a moat on three sides and the house was also open to the River Thames to the north. This allowed access to both the island and the manor house by boat.

It is thoug

In 1215 the castle sustained attack in an epic siege by King John. Having first broken

For 800 years, the Bishops of Winchester used the Castle as a home

properties.name: The Major Oak
properties.narrative:
The massive tree weighs an estimated 23 tons, has a girth of 33 feet (10 metres), and is about 800?1000 years old.

properties.shortnarra: This awesome place was founded by 12 Cistercians in 1131. It was therefore the first Cistercian Abbey in Yorkshire. At its peak, there were 140 monks here.

Kjerag or Kiragg is a

properties.name: Battle Abbey (Partial Ruin)

properties.shortnarra: Battle Abbey is the site of the 1066 Battle of Hastings.

properties.shortnarra: The original - and we mean ORIGINAL - Geysir

properties.name: Grande Cascade de Gavarnie (Gavernie Waterfall)
properties.narrative:
A stunning waterfall, set in even more jaw-dropping surroundings, the Gavernie Waterfall is a temperamental beast. In the hottest of summers, it's a torrent. In winter - even with a sniff of a cold breeze, it just stops flowing.

properties.narrative: It is possible to walk along the hils that surround the cove or along the shingle beach. Access to the area east of the cove is restricted as it is part of a firing range. It is normally only open at weekends and throughout August.
properties.shortnarra: Walk down the road from the car park to the cove. Alternatively, walk along the cliff path for a good view of the cove and Stair Hole, another geological feature.

properties.name: Possible Site of The King Solomon's Mines

properties.shortnarra: Khirbat en Nahas - the name of this site translates from Arabic into English as 'ruins of copper'. This is the site of what archaeologists believe to be an extremely vast copper mine.

Hiding in the wood is an 'Ancient Monument'; a moated earthwork. This is a circular ditch, about 7m wide and 3m deep in places. This encloses an island about 60m across. ;

This island is the likely site of a former moated manorial home, probably
properties.shortnarra: Not much is known about the history of the earthwork. There is no direct evidence for its construction or use.

Piraten used to

properties.name: Kenilworth Castle
properties.narrative: Follow in the footsteps of Queen Elizabeth I in the authentically recreated Elizabethan Garden. Lost to the world for over 400 years, it is now open to visitors once more. Wander through carved arbours and marvel at the bejewelled aviary and marble fount

properties.name: Lindisfarne Castle

properties.address: Off Heygate Bank, Rosedale, North Yorkshire YO18

properties.name: The Bridge of Baysdale Abbey
properties.shortnarra: Although the Abbey (actually a rather small priory) has long gone, the bridge over the small stream which led to it remains ...

properties.shortnarra: In Arthurian legend, this rather flat pool is the home of the Lady of the Lake. This is therefore where King Arthur is said to have received the blade 'Excalibur'.

properties.shortnarra: Beach and various coves

properties.shortnarra: The Old bridge or Ponte Vecchio, the oldest of Florence's six bridges, is one of the city's best known images.

properties.name: The Giant's Grave (Burial Spot of Magog)

properties.name: Guy Fawkes' Trial Manuscript

properties.shortnarra: No-one except the staff seem to know it's here.

It turns green and beautiful every year and dominates the whole area on the edge of the hillside among the juniper trees. Within a stone?s throw from the big oak tree is Norra Kvills National Park.

To get there, follow the road signs from Venzelh

This piece is in good condition, by last reports. It is behind perspex (even though Robbo seems to have tagged it a bit) and therefore quite safe.

properties.shortnarra: The Three Mills are former working mills, one of London?s oldest extant industrial centres.

properties.name: Buckholt Farm Barrows
properties.shortnarra: This probable Bronze Age barrow has been largely levelled by farming but it can still be made out nestled next to Buckholt Wood.

properties.name: Bolton Castle

The Department of War built the fort which surrounds the southern side of the lighthouse. It was completed in 1860.

Colchester had been the first Roman capital of Britain, and the castle is largely built from materials salvaged from the surrounding Roman remains.

The castle was partially demolished in 1683, which has led to much speculation about its original

Middle Temple Hall

properties.shortnarra: One of the four Inns of Court.

properties.name: Basilica of St Junien
properties.narrative: On the south side of the nave, there's a rather unusual 15th century painted statue of 'Christ the Leper'. There are also some impressive frescoes in the gallery chapel.
properties.shortnarra: A large and fine Romanesque Abbey Church.

properties.name: Secret Beach for Locals
properties.narrative: Watch out for the riptide on the far right hand side of the beach. It's powerful.
properties.shortnarra: Bit of trek to get to (you need a 4x4 but worth it).

properties.name: Chaise-Dieu Abbey Church
properties.narrative: Inside the Abbey, there is a very famous mural - called 'The Dance of Death' which is 26m long.

properties.shortnarra: The Abbey stands on a plateau over 1000m above sea level. It was founded in 1044 and the present structure built in 14th century. It was built to withstand attack.

properties.name: The Ebbing and Flowing Well

properties.shortnarra: Ancient little well, which, 'ebbs and flows'.

properties.shortnarra: Thomason Foss is a beautiful waterfall found just north of Goathland in Eller Beck.

properties.name: Berry Pomeroy Castle

It was built in the 15th century as a fortified house for the Pomer
properties.shortnarra: Hidden in a deeply wooded valley, clinging to a jutting rock, Berry Pomeroy Castle is a picture perfect view of a haunted ruined castle.

properties.name: Remaining Part of The Great Palace

properties.name: Egyptian Avenue, Cemetery

Eddy Grant missed out on this one. He could have a whole string of London-area related hits (See Brixton's Electric Avenue point of interest).

Straight out of an Indiana Jones film, walk through
properties.shortnarra: "We're gonna rock down to, Egy--ptian Aven-ueee"

properties.shortnarra: There are actually TWO castles here - the ruin of the original, dating from around 12th century, and the 'new' castle, built in the mid-15th century.

properties.name: 3 The Grove (Coleridge's Old House)

properties.shortnarra: An ancient megalith, rumoured to be older than Stonehenge.

1439 room and one of the few palaces in the world that is used for its original purpose.

properties.shortnarra: Yes, the man who wrote Moby Dick used to live here.

properties.narrative: Svampen, which does translate as 'The Mushroom', is a sculpture by Holger Blom. It is famous in Stockholm. It's had a rough journey - it's been moved around a bit and the current incarnation is a replica of the original. which had been isolated on a traf

properties.shortnarra: Aww, look at 'em! Look!

properties.name: Westminster Cathedral
properties.narrative:
Hey, why let this little fellow's grander relative have all the attention? Get yourself along to Victoria Street and admire this fantastic building. The view from the top is even better.

Read more
properties.shortnarra: Abbey? Or cathedral? Cathedral? Or abbey?

properties.name: Dunstanburgh Castle (Ruins)
properties.shortnarra: Enormous castle ruins, right on the beautiful Northumberland coast, on a headland lashed by the waves. Possibly the largest castle in Northern England.

properties.shortnarra: Cathedral since 1997, this place was built in 1874.

The 400-metre circuit is located next to the Velodrome in the north of the Olympic Par

properties.name: Harewood Castle

It's now ruinous but stands atmospherically on a ridge in the middle of the woodland.

;until recently, was on a buildings at risk register. Happily, it's had some funding and stabilisation work and has been taken off that register.

It wa
properties.shortnarra: This very private stone house and fortress castle (it's deep within the grounds of Harewood House, but visible from the A61 Road) was built in the 12th and 13th centuries.

properties.name: Hornsea Mere
properties.narrative:
The lake was gouged out by glacial action thousands of years ago.

The mere is a 'mere' (ha) 12ft in depth at its deepest point. There is plentiful wildlife and many things to do on the lake such as sailing or boating.

A truly beautiful pl
properties.shortnarra: The largest freshwater lake in England and the largest lake in Yorkshire.

properties.narrative:
This seven-acre botanical park spreads out. It is designed for long, invigorating walks. 
Approximately 2500 different plants. 
The giant 25 meter high greenhouse is one of the largest in the world.

Bus 9, 10, 23, 24 or 26.

properties.narrative: This is how it looked when it was new.

properties.name: Jervaulx Abbey
properties.narrative: The monastery was founded in the 12th century and destroyed about 400 years later. A
properties.shortnarra: Rather spartan remains - with vines and plants growing out of nooks and cracks - of a little known, but once huge, Cistercian abbey.

properties.name: Ruins of Neville Castle
properties.shortnarra: This is the buried and some still-standing remains of a late medieval hunting lodge, said to have been the replacement for the moated manor house, about a half a kilometer to the east.

properties.shortnarra: This shuttered building is said to have been the inspiration for the counting house in Charles Dickens' 'A Christmas Carol'.

properties.shortnarra: Although there is little more to see here than raised earthworks, this area was the site of the massive Roman Fort of Derventio - the original settlement of Malton.

properties.shortnarra: There was a large POW camp at Methley and some of the foundations of the camp can still be seen.

properties.shortnarra: Originally built in 1516 to help defend the old city of Amsterdam. The top half was 'glittered up' a bit just under a century later.

properties.shortnarra: Once a flourmill, this mill is now a popular meeting place for the locals. It's now a brewery and you can swing by here for some cold meats, peanuts and beer. But it fills up QUICKLY!

properties.shortnarra: One of only two wooden houses remaining in the city. Not quite as 'polished' as its cousin over at Begijnhof, this house was built in 1550. It is still unusual, rickety and not without charm.

properties.name: Rock Chapel (Sziklakapolna)
properties.narrative:
When the communists came to power after WW2 this little church was sealed off by them.

It was grandly reopened more than 40 years later following the fall of Communism in Hungary. The church is said to be a copy of a church in L
properties.shortnarra: Little chapel built within a natural cave in Gellert Hill in the early 20th century.

properties.name: Tomb of Samuel Pepys
properties.narrative: He is buried under the nave, inside the church.
properties.shortnarra: Final resting place of the Great London Diarist, with the repeatedly-difficult-to-spell surname

properties.narrative:
Contact venue for pricing (Family tickets available).

(Follow brown tourist signs towards Portland Bill from arrival o

properties.name: Falling Foss Waterfall
properties.shortnarra: A delicate and pretty waterfall, set in a wooded glade and which flows over a small cliff and cascades noisily down the rocks some 30ft to the pool below.

properties.shortnarra: This bridge, constructed in the United Kingdom, was the first permanent bridge across the Danube.

properties.name: Castle Rising
properties.narrative: The stone keep, built in around 1140 AD, is amongst the finest surviving examples of its kind anywhere in the country and, together with the massive surrounding earthworks, ensures that Rising is a castle of national importance. <
properties.address: Castle Rising, King's Lynn, Norfolk PE31 6AH
properties.shortnarra: Castle Rising Castle is one of the most famous 12th Century castles in England.

properties.name: Minster (or Kirkdale) Cave
properties.narrative:
Remains of these animals have not been found any further north than this. What's more than this, the bones of mammoth were also found in the cave. It is thought that hyenas used the cave as their lair and feasted on the larger animals.

Flints hav
properties.shortnarra: Mesolithic cave, discovered in 1821, found to contain the bones of animals which are not currently found in England- tiger, hippopotamus, rhinoceros, elephant and hyena among others.

properties.narrative: The crypt is also notable for the fact that there's a 'hogback' tombstone here. This stone is almost certainly scandinavian in origin, dating from the 10th century. It has a carving of a bear on it.
properties.shortnarra: This interesting church holds the most complete crypt in the country - it's essentially a whole church of its own, beneath the one above it.

properties.name: Statue of Anne Frank
properties.shortnarra: Anne Frank was the little girl who chronicled her experience hiding during the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands during World War II. She recorded her thoughts between 12 June 1942 until 1 August 1944

There is a circular bench inside (carved out of the rock of course) which you can sit on.

The shelter was carved by a local schoolmaster - George Chubb - and his name appears on the shelter, along with the date he carved his name - 1790.
properties.shortnarra: A shelter carved out of a sandstone boulder, which you can fully enter.

properties.name: Old Wooden House (Begijnhof 34)

1st May to 30th September, 10.30AM to 5.30PM, Autumn half term, 11.00AM to 5.30PM

properties.name: Himmelstalund Rock Carvings (Petroglyphs)
properties.shortnarra: The park ?s famous f?r having ?ne ?f Sweden's biggest collection ?f petroglyphs w?th more th?n 1660 pictures.

La D�fense i

properties.name: St Patrick's Church
properties.narrative:
This is reckoned to be the most beautiful parish church in the country. It still holds a service every Sunday.

The church was built between 1300 and 1350 - quite a speedy turnaround for such an intricate building.

The spire stretches some
properties.shortnarra: More of a cathedral in miniature, St Patrick's is an absolute gem and well worth a visit, wherever you're coming from.

properties.name: Little Compton Street (Disappeared Road)
properties.narrative:
With your back to Old Compton Street, look across to the middle island. There's a grate. Dodge the traffic, and peek through the grate.

There you'll see two road signs for the long lost Little Compton Street - a sunken London of yester-century. <
properties.shortnarra: You can view this long forgotten street through the grill which appears in the middle of the road.

properties.name: Victorian Bear Pit
properties.shortnarra: A real bear pit, which saw plenty of use in Victorian times, when two bears were kept here. The pit has been restored, protected and now has a big metal bear in the middle. Grizzly.

properties.name: The White Cross ("Fat Betty")
properties.narrative:
Fat Betty could have been named after a Cistercian nun - the nuns used to wear white robes - or this may have been a marker for pilgrims.

Folklore has that Fat Betty was a farmer's wife and she fell off the farmer's cart on their way home from ma
properties.shortnarra: This cross has two names - officially it's the White Cross but most locals call it 'Fat Betty'. Well, it looks fat doesn't it. It's probably Norman.

properties.name: Skipton Castle
properties.shortnarra: Skipton Castle was founded in the 14th century and has been highly maintained ever since. Consequently it stands as possibly the most complete and best preserved castle in England.

properties.name: Former Entrance to The Blackheath Caverns
properties.narrative: Also known as Jack Cade's Cavern after a rather enterprising chap who sought to make a profit out of charging admission for people to enter them.
properties.shortnarra: Former entrance to massive subterranean chambers, tunnels and caverns, which extend several hundred meters underground.

properties.name: The Earl Grey Tower
properties.shortnarra: Known both as the 'Reform Tower' or the 'Earl Grey Tower', built by William Pole Thornhill and dedicated to the Reform Act 1832.

properties.name: Wapping Old Stairs
properties.narrative:
The stairs themselves have a terrible history - pirates were often brought here, bloated and engorged with water from being washed over by the Thames a number of times. Grisly.

Like all of the old stairs along this stretch, popular with amateur a
properties.shortnarra: A hark back to the time when smugglers, dockers and pirates used to sail these stretches, using these stairs to go on land.

properties.name: Lock Keepers' Cottages
properties.narrative: The Big Breakfast was a British light entertainment television show shown on Channel 4 and S4C each weekday morning from 28 September 1992 until 29 March 2002 during which period 2,482 shows were produced
properties.shortnarra: Geographical nostalgia trip for 30 somethings ...

properties.name: Puy de Crouel (Extinct Volcano)
properties.shortnarra: Although the base is surrounded by pollution and waste, apparently you can still find a path through and a track to the top.

properties.name: Richmond Castle
properties.narrative:
Richmond Castle didn't really see much action and therefore it's in a reasonable state of repair. The only reason it's a bit battered is through neglect rather than by cannonball.

There are two keeps. Scollard's Hall, is a very old style ke
properties.address: Riverside Road Richmond, North Yorkshire DL10 4QW

properties.name: Site of Battle of Stamford Bridge (memorial stone)
properties.shortnarra: The fields near to this memorial stone are believed to be the battlefield where King Harold Goodwinson of England's army totally routed the attacking Norwegian army.

properties.name: The Church of All Saints
properties.address: All Saints Church Office Moseley Street Ripley Derbyshire DE5 3DA
properties.shortnarra: 15th century church with marks on the east wall created by Cromwell's soldiers as they executed Royalist prisoners after the battle of Marston Moor.

properties.name: The Weeping Cross

properties.shortnarra: A very old ?weeping cross? where pilgrims and those who wished to repent, kneeled in prayer.

properties.name: Sight of Tadcaster Castle (earthworks)

All that remains is motte. The outline of the long 
demolished southern bailey can be seen in the impact upon the surrounding 
streets.
properties.shortnarra: Only earthworks (mostly overgrown) exist of the motte and bailey castle William de Percy founded in the 11th century.

properties.name: The Rudston Monolith
properties.narrative:
The monolith - almost 8 metres tall and weighing about 40 tonnes - may have been dragged here over 40 miles from the Cleveland Hills, or may have been deposited somewhere near here by glacial action and then erected by prehistoric man.

Folklore d
properties.shortnarra: The tallest standing stone in Britain - and that's including competition from more famous contenders in Wiltshire - which was probably placed here around 1600BC.

properties.name: La Lanterna (Lighthouse)
properties.shortnarra: This is the oldest European lighthouse in existence.

properties.shortnarra: Large ruinous Cistercian abbey founded in 1147 which nestles beneath large rocks, straddling a stream and beneath the trees. Idyllic.

properties.name: St Helen's Church (and ChurchDoor)
properties.narrative: <span>The original door into this church is famous for its Viking ironwork, and the actual stone doorway depicts a number of beasts, heads and coins. The door itself has rare C-hinges and a small pair of figures, joined by what appears to be a viking lon
properties.shortnarra: This 12th century church has a very famous feature; the southwest wooden door (now permanently fixed in it's 'open' position inside the church) is the original. This means it's almost 1,000 years old.

properties.name: Site of Roxby Castle
properties.shortnarra: That's your lot. Undulations (that's 'bumps' to you and me) in the ground. That's all that remains of this castle. Unfortunately, there's not much to mark the spot - not much of a sight really. Sorry.

properties.name: Madeleine Cave
properties.shortnarra: Feel like you're in a Jules Verne novel in the Grotte Madeleine

properties.name: The 'Bloody Meadow'
properties.narrative:
Cock Beck, which still runs through here, was said to have run red, such was the high quantity of bloodshed.

Many finds - skulls, weapons, trinkets, bones and suchlike are still being unearthed today.

A gruesome place, with an eerie feelin
properties.shortnarra: On this piece of land, thousands and thousands of men were slaughtered in 1461.

properties.name: Towton Cross
properties.narrative:
In 1483 Richard III started to build a chapel to commemorate the battle. He died in battle, just two years later, and the building remained uncompleted, leading to the chapel collapsing.

The ruins were, apparently, still discernible 500 years lat
properties.shortnarra: A cross commemorating the Battle of Towton and those who died participating in it.

properties.name: Loughrigg Caves
properties.narrative: <font color="#000000">The cave is situated on Loughrigg Fell. This is a man-made cavern, which was formerly known as Loughrigg Quarry. The cave has been hollowed out of a rocky outcrop which overlooks Rydal Water. Over two hundred years ago Rydal Cave wa
properties.shortnarra: Interesting cavern, filled with water with stepping stones leading inside ...

properties.name: Tickhill Castle (Ruins and Earthworks)
properties.narrative: Tickhill was a Royal Castle, like York and Nottingham. It is reported to have been a tremendously powerful one, with thick walls, a motte 75 feet high and 80 feet in diameter. The bailey covers some two acres. The bailey is protected by huge ramparts and
properties.shortnarra: All that remains of this mighty place is the mound on which the keep once stood, the roofless gatehouse and some curtain wall.

properties.name: The Hermitage
properties.narrative: Discovered in October 1854 by workmen laying a new sewer in Southgate, there are two subterranean chambers here, together with a well. These are reached by a spiral staircase of 63 steps. There is also an oratory. Everything appears to have been excavate

properties.name: Durham Obelisk
properties.narrative: Very tall slender obelisk, with 3 openings on south face, stands on high panelled base with cornice; steps down to small opening at foot on north side. South face inscribed with latitude, longitude, angle of dip and height above sea level. Believed to be
properties.shortnarra: Obelisk, built as an observation point in around1850.

properties.name: Zytglogge
properties.narrative: The clock also has figures which revolve at approximately four minutes before the hour. Following this, the clock sounds the hour.

properties.name: The Bock
properties.narrative:

properties.name: Iguazu Falls
properties.narrative:
The fall is made up of hundreds of smaller waterfalls, depending on rainfall. In terms of surface water flowing over the falls, Iguazu Falls is over twice as large as the perhaps more famous Niagara Falls.

It's been featured in both Bond and India
properties.shortnarra: Quite terrifying waterfall ("big water") on the borders of Brazil and Argentina. It falls around 269 feet.

properties.name: The Millenium Cross
properties.shortnarra: The largest cross in the world, 66 metres high up. This cross is on the site of a much smaller cross which has lived up there for years.

properties.name: Seljalandsfoss
properties.narrative: It is very picturesque and therefore its photo can be found in many books and calendars. It was a waypoint during the first leg of The Amazing Race 6. The waterfall is situated in between Selfoss and Sk�gafoss at the road crossing of Route 1 (the Rin
properties.shortnarra: Seljalandsfoss is one of the most famous - and perhaps prettiest - waterfalls of Iceland.

properties.name: Dajbabe Monastery
properties.shortnarra: Astounding monastery, built into the cliffs, a joint effort by man and nature.

properties.name: Front Wall and Clock of The Old Town Railway Station
properties.shortnarra: The old railway station. The clock on the front shows 5:17 am. It doesn't move. And hasn't since that time, when on 26 July 1963, a huge earthquake destroyed most of the city- except for this building.

properties.name: The Royston Cave
properties.narrative:
Its most remarkable feature is an extensive range of wall carvings representing the Crucifixion, the Holy Family and several saints, including St Christopher.

Other carvings are less easily identified and it's been suggested
properties.shortnarra: Royston Cave is unique in Europe. Believed to date from the 14th Century, it is a man-made cavern in the shape of a beehive, with a small aperture at the top for ventilation.

properties.name: Singing Ringing Tree
properties.narrative: Catching the westerly winds, the pipes emit an intriguing melodic sound, only audible at close range.
properties.shortnarra: The Singing Ringing Tree is an isolated musical installation to be found at Crown Point, high on the moors looking over the town of Burnley.

properties.name: Netley Abbey
properties.address: 4 miles SE of Southampton, facing Southampton Water
properties.shortnarra: Reputedly Haunted and ruinous abbey

properties.name: Brimham Rocks
properties.narrative: There are many different formations to see and this place makes an ideal outing and picnic spot. Most of the formations have names which suggest what they look like: Chimney Rock, Dancing Bear, Druid's Skull and the Idol Rock (currently pictured).
properties.shortnarra: A natural collection of rather weird and wonderful rock formations, scattered around a large heathland site.

properties.name: St Mary's Church
properties.narrative:
On the inside south door of this little church, there are marks - which look to be scorch marks.

This is supposed to be the point of impact where the devil struck the door in fury. Being the hallowed south door of the church
properties.shortnarra: Did the devil visit this building and leave its mark on the door?

properties.name: Merevale Abbey Ruins
properties.shortnarra: These ruins are located just west of Atherstone in a field. Get to them by walking the short way guided by signposts.

properties.name: Arbor Low (Stone Circle and Gib Hill Barrow)

Within an earthen bank and ditch, a circle of some 50 white limestone slabs, all now fallen, surrounds a central stone ?cove? ? a feature found only in incredibly important sacred sites.

Nearby is myster

properties.shortnarra: No-one's really quite sure when this aquaduct was built. It's 386 meters long with 55 arches. It was a lot longer at one time, plainly. The water was taken from the spring Lavovec in Gluvo into Skopje.

properties.name: Palm Oil Depot
properties.narrative: The oil get pumped up to the big tank on the hill. To later be shipped to the north to become diesel.
properties.shortnarra: As the banana industry left town, the Arabic palm oil became the new income. Here you can see the trucks deliver palm oil from the plantations in the south zone.

properties.name: Grey's Monument
properties.address: Grey Street/Blackett Street, Newcastle Upon Tyne

properties.name: Stone Castle
properties.shortnarra: Building commenced in around 1135 and was completed in 1140. The castle is said to be on the site where King William ('the Conqueror') signed a treaty with the men of Kent in 1067.

properties.name: Site of Former Roman Villa
properties.address: Half Way between Vanbrugh and Maze Hill Exits
properties.shortnarra: This was an area in which a Roman tiled floor was found. This was the location of a Roman villa. Incredibly difficult to find.

properties.name: Cathedral of St. John the Divine
properties.address: 1047 Amsterdam Ave  New York, NY 10025, United States

properties.name: Chrysler Building
properties.address: 405 Lexington Ave  New York, NY 10174, United States
properties.shortnarra: Stunning Art Deco building, over 1,000 feet high, with a snazzy porcupine-look roof. Used to have a viewing deck on the 45th, but this is now closed. Only the amazing lobby is open to the public.

properties.name: The Grand Central Terminal
properties.address: 87 E 42nd St New York, NY 10017, United States
properties.shortnarra: We had to use that picture. This place is beautiful in its own right. But step in and you're immediately on the set of a hundred Hollywood films and art-house pictures.

properties.name: The Brooklyn Bridge
properties.address: Brooklyn Bridge New York, NY 10038, United States
properties.shortnarra: A visually stunning bridge which is often ignored. Go visit it. You're guaranteed some cracking pictures - it's just SO photogenic (especially on the south-eastern Brooklyn side).

properties.name: 911 Memorial Park
properties.address: One Liberty Plaza, 20th Floor New York, NY 10006
properties.shortnarra: A peaceful, beautiful yet profoundly sad place to visit. Make sure you consider the symbolism of the water mixing in confusion before tumbling into the central abyss in the pools. And make a donation.

properties.name: Girton College
properties.shortnarra: In 1976, it was Cambridge's first women's college to become coeducational. Girton is housed in beautiful buildings, 2.5 miles outside of Cambridge proper.

properties.name: Severndroog Castle
properties.shortnarra: Severndroog Castle was built in 1784 as a memorial to Sir William James. It's not really a castle, but a folly - it lies hidden in the middle of some woods.

properties.name: Lesnes Abbey (ruin)
properties.shortnarra: The year 1178 saw the foundation of the Abbey of St Mary and St Thomas the Martyr at Lesnes.

properties.name: Site of Bermondsey Abbey
properties.shortnarra: Neither the house nor the Abbey still stand, but two hooks of the abbey gate can be seen nearby at 7 Grange Walk, as well as a plaque on Abbey Street and many local street names.

properties.name: 'Stompy' the Tank
properties.shortnarra: Yes, South London has it's very own tank - called 'Stompy' and it's a Soviet T-34. Apparently owned by Russell Gray, who lives nearby. It's been graffiti'd a number of times. Go and enjoy a landmark.

properties.name: The York Watergate
properties.shortnarra: The gates in Embankment Gardens seem out of place. They mark what used to be the bottom of a mansion's garden, leading into the Thames. The Thames was later narrowed, leaving them literally high & dry.

properties.name: The Ancient House
properties.shortnarra: A truly ancient building both in name and by nature. The timber framed, medieval, Ancient House dates from the 1400s. It has of course been restored since, but retains precisely its character & charm.

properties.name: Vinegar Alley - The Site of Plague Pits
properties.shortnarra: The site of a 'plague pit' - where bodies were buried during the Plague 1665. Vinegar may be a reference to the use of vinegar as a form of disinfectant, the best they had back then.

properties.name: The Banqueting House
properties.shortnarra: Built in 1622, this magnificent building is the only surviving bit of the former palace of White Hall, which this largely governmental area is named for.

properties.name: Cliffords Inn Gatehouse
properties.shortnarra: The first inn of chancery to be established and the last to be demolished. Only this gatehouse remains, tucked away off Fleet Street.

properties.name: Horsleydown Old Stairs
properties.narrative: The Anchor Brewhouse site is here (mentioned by Chaucer and Shakespeare among others) and, following on from that, the unusual name is believed to relate to this industry. It is said to derive from the instruction 'horse lie down' to the shirehorses who
properties.shortnarra: Another intriguingly named corner of London, where renovation and development seemed to have passed by. This gloomy stairway/alleyway leads directly down to the lapping waters of the Thames.

properties.name: Curtea Veche
properties.shortnarra: This place was built as a palace during the rule of Vlad III Dracula in the 1400s. It's now an interesting museum.

properties.name: The Square House
properties.shortnarra: Formerly 'The Stage House' - lying on the old Boston Post Road - this is a 'new' building, built in the 1700s. George Washington stayed here on two occasions - and was quite pleased with it.

properties.name: The Scene of Bill Sikes' Death
properties.address: The Mud of St Saviour's Dock, Bermondsey, London
properties.shortnarra: The evil Bill Sikes, from the novel 'Oliver Twist' by Charles Dickens, falls from his den to his death into the stinking mud of Folly Ditch (St Saviour's Dock).

properties.name: Aireyholme Farm
properties.address: Aireyholme Farm, Aireyholme Lane, Great Ayton, N. Yorkshire
properties.shortnarra: This is the farm where Captain James Cook grew up.

properties.name: Appearance of the 'Lost' River Neckinger
properties.narrative: Pirates would be hanged at the mouth of this river - and be allowed to swing gently by their necks here on full public display. It was hoped that this would dissuade others from succumbing to the temptations of piracy. The river took its name from the ha
properties.shortnarra: The ancient river Neckinger outfalls into St Saviour's Dock, here, the dock having been built around it, the rest of the river covered up with South London development.

properties.name: Henry VIII's Wine Cellar
properties.address: Beneath the Ministry of Defence, Whitehall
properties.shortnarra: Hidden away in a basement below the Ministry of Defence, this vaulted chamber is a former palace undercroft and one of the only remaining parts of the medieval palace. NOT open to the public.

properties.name: Horse Guards Clock
properties.shortnarra: Notice the clock on top of the main building and the black mark at 2pm. This is a mark, made out of respect for King Charles I, who in 1641 was executed across the street during the English Civil War.

properties.name: The Oldest Statue in London
properties.shortnarra: Yes, it's Alfred the Great. The poor lad's been booted out of Westminster Hall in the Houses of Parliament to down here. The statue dates from the 1300s, making Alf over 700 years old.

properties.name: Round Hill (Motte and Bailey Earthwork Castle)
properties.shortnarra: Mound of earth which formed part of a strategic lookout at the confluence of the two rivers leading into Yarm.

properties.name: "Big Ben" (Elizabeth's Tower)
properties.narrative:
Yes, yes, it's only the bell which is called 'Big Ben'. The tower used to be called St Stephen's Tower. Very recently, (September 2012) it was renamed Elizabeth's Tower.

And it needs to be this big and important to make sure
properties.shortnarra: "I say, what a magnificent clock"

properties.name: The Grave of 'Giro', the Nazi Dog
The Tower House
properties.shortnarra: Records mentioning the tower date back to 1585, but the foundations are probably medieval. It is likely that an older tower existed on the same spot and was part of the wall that surrounded Canterbury.

properties.name: Palace of Arts/Palats Mastatsva
properties.shortnarra: The Art Palace is a hip haunt in Minsk. Whether to admire modern art, browse book stalls, haggle with antique vendors or simply people-watch, this is the place to get a feel for the city.

properties.name: Whitby Castle
properties.narrative: No longer is this a private dwelling but a private club - the Rye Golf club. If you show much interest, perhaps you could persuade them to take you for a tour. Failing that, just admire this beautiful building ;from the outside.
properties.address: 330 Boston Post Rd  Rye, NY 10580, United States
properties.shortnarra: Castle built not as a fortification but as a private residence in 1852. It's called Whitby as the construction contains original stones from Whitby Castle in England (the one which inspired Dracula).

properties.name: The Old Royal Naval College
properties.shortnarra: Take a walk around here either early morning or evening, just before sunset. It reeks of history and the atmosphere here is amazing.

properties.name: The Fountain
properties.address: Lovers' Walk, Greenwich Park, Greenwich, London
properties.shortnarra: Small rustic looking fountain in a dark, cool dell. Quite hidden and you may have walked past this a number of times without noticing it.

properties.name: Weird Little Sign Which Can't Be Read
properties.shortnarra: A little stone 'plaque', set into an out of place gatepost on this road, somewhere near to number 47. It says something about 9 inches, and something about an estate. Good luck reading the rest.

properties.name: Staubbach Falls
properties.shortnarra: With a height of nearly 300 meters, Staubbach Falls is the second highest waterfall in Switzerland. It nestles in a beautiful valley with about 70 other waterfalls near the town of Lauterbrunnen.

properties.name: Somerset House (York) Watergate
properties.narrative: <font color="#000000">This watergate now some distance from the Thames - was an entrance into Somerset House from the Thames. This illustrates quite vividly how close the Thames River used to run to the Strand ('strand' being a germanic word for 'beach')
properties.shortnarra: The entrance to the Palace from the Thames

properties.name: Mirador
properties.shortnarra: WOW!! Best view of Golfo Dulce. Follow the road in Limbo(by the soccerfield) all the way up to the radio tower.

properties.name: Caesar's Well
properties.shortnarra: This little grove, and the spring at its centre, is the source of the River Ravensbourne which ultimately flows into the Thames.

properties.name: The Remains of a Princess' Sunken Bath
properties.address: Charlton Way Entrance to Greenwich Park, Greenwich, London
properties.shortnarra: Princess Caroline was the wife of George IV, Prince Regent (yes, the stupid one). She had a fine house here and used to party in it regularly. When she left, George demolished it. This is the remains.

properties.name: Small Elephant Statues
properties.shortnarra: These perching elephants are all that remain of the former 'Elephant & Castle' public house. Paul 'O Grady's Lily Savage first took to the stage here too.

properties.name: The Temple Bar
properties.shortnarra: The point where the City of Westminster boundary reaches the City of London boundary. The monarch stops here before entering the City of London. There used to be a huge 'bar' here. Now near St Paul's.

properties.name: Talbot Yard - The Beginning of The Canterbury Tales
properties.narrative: The precise site of the inn is now housed well within the 'Copyprints' Business Centre. A blue plaque adorns the wall so you can see where it was. ;
properties.shortnarra: Chaucer's band of reprobates set out from the stable yard of 'The Tabard' Inn on this spot. It's now called Talbot Yard. Chaucer himself set out from here, giving him material for the story.

properties.name: 350 Year Old House
properties.shortnarra: Walnut Tree House is Leyton's oldest building and is thought to have been built in the mid 1500s; a sundial in the grounds was found marked 1666. Also known as 'Essex House'.

properties.name: St Nicholas Church/ Chris Marlowe's Remains
properties.narrative: Don't forget to look out for the Charnel House - built to deter grave-robbers from the graveyard and also the grisly looking skull and crossbones perched on top of the gateposts. ;
properties.shortnarra: In this church graveyard, the bones of the great poet and playwright Christopher Marlowe are buried. They lie underneath a memorial plaque which can be seen on the wall in the churchyard.

properties.name: Oldest Remaining Shopfront in London
properties.shortnarra: This beautiful shop front is Georgian and dates from 1756. Whilst in use, it remained a shop. This street was formerly known as 'Raven Row' - this being number 4. Now exhibits contemporary art.

properties.name: 'Jacob' the Dray Horse Statue
properties.shortnarra: The famous Courage dray horses were stabled on this site from the early nineteenth century and delivered beer around London from the brewery on Horselydown Lane by Tower Bridge.

properties.name: An Assorted Bunch of Anchors
properties.shortnarra: Totally free and well away from the usual touristy sights are these real artefacts from Greenwich's maritime history. Some are clean, some are not, but they illustrate the different anchor designs.

properties.name: The Nagasaki Angel
properties.shortnarra: This wee beastie (only about half a metre tall) was part of a church in Nagasaki, Japan - the only surviving remnant following its near total destruction when an atom bomb fell on 09 August 1945.

properties.name: Rodin Museum
properties.shortnarra: His personal collection and archives, in a charming home with garden.

properties.name: Teesaurus Park
properties.shortnarra: Top prehistoric fun with steel being bent into dinosaur shapes on this threatened 10 acre site.

properties.name: Canterbury Cathedral
properties.shortnarra: Possibly the finest example of medieval architecture in England and which can trace its foundations to its nave, founded in the 6th century. This place also houses the shrine to Saint Thomas Becket.

properties.name: Precise Site of St George's Gate
properties.shortnarra: St George?s Gate is not of Roman origin. Its site now sits at the eastern end of the main axis of the city. Some clever dark cobbling shows you how narrow and tight this entrance to the city was.

properties.name: Poundbury Hill Fort
properties.shortnarra: Grassy mounds and ditches reveal this fort's existence. The main entrance is on the eastern end. It dates from at least 600AD.

properties.name: Site of the Original Globe Theatre
properties.shortnarra: Here on Parker Street you can see the plaque for the Globe but behind that, and possibly missed by some people, is the actual Globe, or rather markings on the ground showing where the foundations were.

properties.name: Outfall of the River Fleet
properties.narrative: From a little sluice, the once might River Fleet churns out and joins the Thames. It is, nowadays, not much more than a large stream. The best place to view the discharge from is the little walkway called 'Blackfriars Millenium Pier'. Although you can
properties.shortnarra: This is where the long-since buried and once mighty River Fleet discharges into the Thames.

properties.name: Site of Middlesbrough FC's Old Ground 'Ayresome Park'
Strand Underground Station (Disused)
properties.shortnarra: Former station of the Picadilly line permitting direct access to The Strand. Now no longer a transport choice but there are occasional open days and tours.

properties.name: Soldier on a Camel Statue
properties.shortnarra: A nifty little statue, sat on a plinth and dedicated to the Imperial Camel Corps.

properties.name: 'Little Ireland'
properties.shortnarra: It was inhabited for about 20 years from about 1827 to 1847 and was given its name from the presence of many poor Irish immigrants here. It was a slum district.

properties.name: "The Old Curiosity Shop"
properties.narrative: <font color="#000000">This striking building was built in 1567 and, looking at it, you can tell. Doggedly resisting the temptation to fall by both the Great Fire of London and the bombs of World War II, this is surely one of the city's remaining 'olde wo
properties.shortnarra: Apparently the shop after which Dickens named his little book

properties.name: Only Remnant of the Old Medieval London Bridge
properties.shortnarra: Yes, this archway was the pedestrian entrance to the famous old bridge (NOT the one shipped to America) and attached, as it is know to St Magnus the Martyr.

properties.name: The Black Gate
properties.address: Castle Garth  Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne and Wear NE1 1RQ

properties.name: Canterbury Castle
properties.shortnarra: Remains of a medieval moated castle, originally established by William I, then strengthened by William II and completed by Henry I in 1120.

properties.name: St Martin's Church
properties.address: North Holmes Road, Canterbury, Kent CT1 1PW
properties.shortnarra: The oldest Church in the English speaking world still used for worship. Used by St Augustine to set up his mission to convert the English to Christianity in 597AD. You can still worship here.

properties.name: The Remaining Tower of the Church of St Mary Magdalene
properties.shortnarra: This tower is all that remains of the once mighty medieval church of St Mary Magdalene. The tower is a 1503 rebuilding of an earlier structure.

properties.name: The Site of The Riding Gate
properties.shortnarra: Riding Gate was one of the original six main gates that formed part of the fortifications that the Romans built between AD250-270. There is very little left to see.

properties.name: Christ Church Gate
properties.shortnarra: Records indicate that this spectacular main gate to the cathedral was built between 1504 and 1521.

properties.name: Old Eldon Square War Memorial
properties.address: Old Eldon Square, Newcastle Upon Tyne, UK
properties.shortnarra: A statue of St George slaying a dragon, mounted high on a plinth.

properties.name: Trinity House
properties.address: Broad Chare  Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne and Wear NE1 3DQ
properties.shortnarra: This beautiful place was founded in the mid fifteenth century when a group of sailors and seafarers formed it.

properties.name: The Abandoned Island in the Middle of New York
properties.shortnarra: North Brother Island is a small island in the East River between the Bronx and Riker's Island, New York City. Once the site of a hospital, it is now uninhabited and designated as a bird sanctury.

properties.name: St Dunstan's Church (Religious Artefact)
properties.narrative: Today, St Dunstan's is a place of pilgrimage for many. ;
properties.shortnarra: The 'Roper' family vault beneath St Nicholas chapel contains the head of a man, said to have belonged to Thomas More. More was beheaded for refusing to accept evil Henry VIII as head of the Church.

properties.name: Extremely Crooked House (Sir John Boy's House)
properties.shortnarra: An ancient half-timbered house which has slipped sideways, to a rather staggering degree - caused by modifications to an internal chimney. Not open to the public.

properties.name: Ancient Cogan's House (in Zizzi's Restaurant)
properties.shortnarra: This ancient stone house, dating from the early 13th century now houses Zizzi's restaurant. If you'd like to look at some awesome wooden stairs and features, get yourself into Zizzi's.

properties.name: Site of Christopher Marlowe's Birthplace
properties.shortnarra: The great poet and all round literary superhero was born in a house on this site. Sadly, it was bombed to bits in WWII. Oh, how he'd turn in his grave - secret supersleuth birthplace turned Superdrug.

properties.name: St Augustine's Abbey
properties.shortnarra: The abbey was founded around AD 598 as part of St Augustine's mission and housed the monks who came with him. A fascinating place to wander around. And very peaceful.

properties.name: Canterbury West Gate
properties.address: 2 St. Peters Street, Canterbury, Kent, England
properties.shortnarra: Dating from 1380, this was the main gate into the city from the West. It's 60ft high and was one of the only gates through the city walls.

properties.name: St George?s Church Tower and Clock
properties.shortnarra: The original St George?s church dated back to Norman times. The present tower is probably 15th century. Canterbury?s famous poet, Christopher 'Kit' Marlowe was baptised in the church.

properties.name: Site of Canterbury Guildhall
properties.shortnarra: The Guildhall stood here for 770 years, home to local government and justice. It was also used for music concerts and a young W A Mozart played here in 1765. Only a plaque remains.

properties.name: Big Power Station
properties.shortnarra: The four chimneys of this hulking chunk of industry dominate the area - the can be seen from just about everywhere in nearby Greenwich Park.

properties.name: All Saints Church, Blackheath
properties.shortnarra: The parish church for Blackheath Village.

properties.name: Cathedral Church of St Mary
properties.address: Clayton St W  Newcastle upon Tyne NE1 5HH

properties.name: Sutton Scarsdale Hall
properties.address: Hall Drive Sutton Scarsdale, Chesterfield, Derbyshire S44 5UR
properties.shortnarra: A rather haunting shell of a former imposing hall.

properties.name: The white mulberrytree
properties.shortnarra: One of the few white mulberry trees in malm�.

properties.name: Manchester Cathedral
properties.shortnarra: Manchester Cathedral is a medieval church in Manchester, England seat of the Bishop of Manchester.

properties.name: Mamucium Roman Fort (Remains)
properties.shortnarra: The remains of the fort are protected as a Scheduled Ancient Monument. It guarded the road between the legionary fortresses of Deva Victrix (Chester) and Eboracum (York). Some reconstruction.

properties.name: Site of the Hat & Feathers Pub - a Gangster's Paradise
properties.address: 39 Mason St Manchester, Lancashire County M4 5FX
properties.shortnarra: This was the location of the Hat & Feathers, a fine example of a corner back street public house - and also one time HQ of Eric Mason, a well known gangster.

properties.name: Fancy GatePosts with a Crest
properties.shortnarra: Have no idea what these are but they're here, and I'd like to know.

properties.name: Wincobank Fort (Site of)
properties.narrative: Now, largely overgrown, you can nonetheless still make out the concentric rings which surrounded the original camp.
properties.shortnarra: Iron Age Hill Fort. There has been a fort on this site since at least c500 BC according to carbon dating conducted in 1979.

properties.name: Pilsbury Castle (Site of)
properties.shortnarra: Peaks, dips and troughs of a former motte and bailey castle.

properties.name: St Mary's the Hidden Gem
properties.narrative: This is where the funeral of Tony Adams was held. Mr Adams was the founder of the famous Factory Records label. ;
properties.shortnarra: Originally surrounded by slums, this little church is wedged down a street and really is quite hidden. Inside, you'll find a beautiful church and the Adams Stations of the Cross.

properties.name: Piccadilly Records
properties.shortnarra: Absolutely bloody legendary record store.

properties.name: An Ancient Gnarled Tree
properties.shortnarra: Lots of fun. There's me in it, look.

properties.name: Smaller, Derbyshire Stone-Henge
properties.narrative: <font color="#000000" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Almost invisible beneath a thick covering of heather and tall grasses. No paths pass anywhere near it - the nearest track is 500 metres away and reaching the circle from here involves an arduous u
properties.shortnarra: Called 'The Chair Stone' and 'Wet Withens'

properties.name: Sheffield Manor Castle
properties.shortnarra: The remains of an old hunting lodge, which was once situated in a vast medieval park.

properties.name: Ruined Catholic Chapel
properties.shortnarra: This was 'Trinity Chapel', built by an Italian Mission sometime in the late 17th Century.

properties.name: The Sailor's Stone
properties.narrative:
The inscription on the stone reads:
"In detestation of a barbarous Murder, ;Committed here on an unknown Sailor, ;On Sep, 24th 1786, ;By Edwd. Lonegon, Mich. Casey & Ja
properties.shortnarra: Site of a bloody murder of an unfortunate sailor, travelling along the old London to Portsmouth Road.

properties.name: Old Knepp Castle
properties.shortnarra: Built in the 12th century by William de Braose.

properties.name: Celtic Cross
properties.narrative:
The cross has four Latin inscriptions around its base. They read:

POST TENEBRAS LUX
IN OBITU PAX
IN LUCE SPES
POST OBITUM SALUS

which translate to "Light after darkness. Peace in passing a
properties.shortnarra: Erected in the 19th century to dispel a fear among travelers across the Downs that this place was haunted by evil spirits.

properties.name: Gibbet Hill
properties.shortnarra: Just shy of 900 feet above sea level, and many prominent London landmarks can be seen from up here on a clear day. Previously the haunt of robbers and highwaymen - some ended up in a noose up here.

properties.name: Discover The Devil's Punchbowl
properties.shortnarra: Area of outstanding natural beauty, a huge natural ampitheatre in the Surrey countryside. A rich folklore surrounds this place and it's a beautiful place to explore.

properties.name: St Michael's Church
properties.narrative:
Among the subjects covered by the carvings are; St Michael slaying a dragon, Samson and the Nemean Lion, a scene which looks like the nativity, the labours of the month and other spectacular figures and beasts.

Worth a look if you're passing thro
properties.shortnarra: Unusual church encompassing original Norman Style carving work form 1160 and new, rebuilt in 1871.

properties.name: Shire Hall
properties.shortnarra: This grand old place was built in 1779 and currently houses court rooms.

properties.name: Castle Hill Fort (Earthworks)
properties.shortnarra: This is the site of enormous defensive earthworks dating back to around 1086.

properties.name: Remains of Roman Settlement
properties.narrative: <font face="Arial, Verdana" size="2">This area used to be closer to the sea than it is now. The water was drained away, forming the modern day Romney Marshes. The remains of this settlement show how far inland the sea used to reach. ;</font>
properties.shortnarra: Portus Lemanis is the name of this ancient Roman fort, settlement and port. Known locally as Stutfall Castle, it's on private land. Ask permission first.

properties.name: Manneken Pis Statue
properties.shortnarra: The icon of Belgium. A urinating, gleeful looking child. It's only 61cm tall but the identity it provides for the citizens of Brussels (and indeed Belgium) is enormous. It often appears in costume.

properties.name: King?s Quoit Cromlech
properties.shortnarra: A megalithic tomb consisting of a large flat stone laid on upright ones.

properties.name: Rhossili Standing Stone
properties.shortnarra: Only about a metre tall and possibly an ancient boundary marker.

properties.name: Caribbean Conservation Corporation
properties.narrative: From March through October volunteers can assist scientists with turtle tagging and research on green and leather- back turtles. During bird-migration seasons (March through May and August through October) volunteers can
properties.shortnarra: Research station that has a small visitor center and museum. Exhibits focus on all things turtle-related, including a video about the his- tory of local turtle conservation.

properties.name: Maison de la Bellone
properties.shortnarra: This amazing 18th century place has a glass vaulted courtyard and there are exhibitions and concerts held here.

properties.name: The Monument to the Martyrs of the 1830 Revolution
properties.narrative: For visiting the crypt, contact Adrien Lenaerts, rue Lt. J. Becker 8, 1040 Brussels, tel: 0477/21 07 33.
properties.shortnarra: A square in classical style which was designed in 1775. It commemorates the heroes who died in the 1830 revolution. Little known, there is a crypt here, which can be toured with groups.

properties.name: Museo Histo?rico Marino
properties.shortnarra: Aquarium that showcases manta rays and other creatures from the Pacific. The park sits on the site of the old train station and has a tiny splash pool, snack bar, gift shop and information center.

properties.name: Saint John the Baptist at the B�guinage
properties.shortnarra: Italian-influenced Flemish Baroque style church of the 17th century.

properties.name: Jeanneke Pis Statue
properties.address: Impasse de la Fid�lit� 10-12, 1000 Bruxelles, Belgium
properties.shortnarra: An opposite number to the more famous Mannekin Pis statue. It's only about half a metre tall but she looks happy enough.

properties.name: The Royal Palace
properties.shortnarra: Official residence of the King and Queen of the Belgians (they don't live here). Fortifications have been here since the 11th century but the facade was built after 1900. Open to the public in summer.

properties.name: Leopold II Statue
properties.shortnarra: Yes, he is controversial, being guilty of genocide - of about 10 million people, but he is very much part of Belgium's history.

properties.name: Atomium
properties.shortnarra: This symbol of Brussels (the capital of Europe), was built for the world fair which took place here in 1958. Go to the upper sphere and take a view of the city, from 92m up.

properties.name: Jarstadheia
properties.narrative: Follow road 57 from Dale towards Flekke and turn right where you see a wooden sign that says " Rakneberg ". There is a possibility to walk all the way from Dale center, but then you'll have to walk for about twenty minutes in a narrow and very busy road
properties.shortnarra: Great hike! It takes about two hours to walk up to the top from the parking, and about an hour to get down again. But on a sunny day there is a great danger you might just want to stay, so bring food!

properties.name: La Casa de la Cultura
properties.shortnarra: Art gallery with occasional exhibits as well as a perform- ance space offering seasonal cultural events. 10am-4pm Mon-Fri

properties.name: Basilique du Sacre-Coeur
properties.address: Parvis de la Basilique 1, 1083 Bruxelles, Belgium
properties.shortnarra: The fifth largest church in the world.

properties.name: Ralston & Bau
properties.shortnarra: Prestigious design agency located in an amazing building with a facade looking like bunches of paper sheets!

properties.name: Dalsfjordbrua
properties.shortnarra: Amazing view! ( Like everywhere else here) You can walk from Dale center through the old tunnels and out on the bridge. A different kind of hike, lots of wind and maybe some cars, but very refreshing!

properties.name: Jakob Sande-tunet
properties.shortnarra: Klokkargarden is the birthplace of the famous norwegian poet Jakob Sande (1906- 67)

properties.name: Finca La Isla Botanical Garden
properties.narrative: Part of the farm is set aside as a botanical garden, which is also good for birding and for wildlife observation (look for sloths and poison-dart frogs). The informati
properties.shortnarra: A working tropical farm where the owners have been growing local spices, tropical fruits and ornamental plants for more than a decade.

properties.name: Dale Church
properties.shortnarra: The white wooden church was built in 1864 and it was consecrated on 24 November of that year by the Dean Johan Carl Christie. The church seats about 550 people.

properties.name: Nordic Artists' Centre Dale
properties.narrative: These amazing facilities are designed by the architects Haga & Grov from Stavanger, in collaboration with architects Hjeltnes and Egge.There is a big building containing the artists studios and a workshop and there are five small cabins on a row in t
properties.shortnarra: Here, artist from all over the world come to little Dale for artist residency. They can enjoy amazing facilities which are SO worth a look.

properties.name: Bird House
properties.narrative: Walk along "Elvestien" from Dale center, over the bridge and up the hill. When you come to a flat area, take to the right and go straight into the birch woods. There is no track, but keep on walking a couple of metres and soon you will discover some stro
properties.shortnarra: A mysterious destination in Berge a short walk from Dale center.

properties.name: Matchstick Men
properties.narrative: ' Matchstick Men' - Wolfgang Stiller / Dale Ferry quay

properties.name: Column of the Congress and the Monument of the Unknown soldier
properties.shortnarra: Erected between 1850 and 1859, this 47m tall column commemorates the creation of the Belgian State. Leopold I is plonked on top. There are stairs inside and visitors can climb to the top for ace views

properties.name: The Shipwreck of the Helvetia
properties.shortnarra: This Russian ship was wrecked here in 1887. Its skeleton lies on the beach and can be seen at low tide.
